desc.size: Biennial or perennial herb, 20 - 80 cm tall, erect.

part.partText: with stiff, appressed, pick-shaped hairs. Usually single but occasionally two or three arise from the base.
short-stalked, oblong, hairy, in a rosette.
alternate, upright, clasping the stem, stalkless, 1 - 3 cm long, oblong to lance-shaped, margins toothed on lower leaves, margins becoming smooth on upper leaves, hairless or nearly so.
in loosely branched clusters, white or yellowish white, 3 - 5 mm long. Petals 4. Stamens 6: 4 tall, 2 short.
a narrow pod, erect or pressed against the stem, 3 - 5 cm long, 0.7 - 1.1 mm wide, linear, flat. Seeds in 1 row.

similarSpecies.comments: Arabis hirsuta var. adpressipilis is distinguished from A. hirsuta by having appressed hairs.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Extremely rare in the Chicago Region because of the scarcity of its special habitats. It grows on shaded, moss-covered limestone boulders along the borders of streams in small rock canyons. It also grows on the vertical walls of limestone canyons. Another habitat is shaded floodplains. Near Romeoville in Will County, Illinois it is found on a disturbed gravelly prairie. This variety has also been observed growing in sandy soil.

etymology.comments: Arabis comes from the Latin word for Arabia (where some species of these herbs originated). Hirsuta means hairy. Adpressipilis means “with adpressed (flattened) hairs.”
